question: Maria Elizabete Marais, Seniors Cottage, Room 22, Devilliers School. They don't call it 'Fortress Virgin' for nothing. You'll never get in.

question: Jan Piet Marais. My uncle. At 22 he led a kommando for three years before your people caught him and hung him.
answer: My people?

question: The English.
answer: I consider myself an African, sir.

question: As do I. As do the Zulu, the Xhosa, the Pongo, the Ndebele. We're all Africans. But all from separate tribes, ay?
answer: Unfortunately.

answer: Because it's the whole tribal idea that creates our problems here in South Africa.

question: The problems of South Africa, my boy, do not come from tribalism. They come from counter-tribalism. Does the rhino graze with the mouse? The separation of things is not coincidental. Do you think a Zulu wants to see his culture, his sense of identity, replaced by someone else's anymore than I do?
answer: No, sir. But I don't think he wants being a Zulu to mean he is denied the same rights as everyone else has.

question: Which is why civilization is defined by the ability to live under the rule of law. Laws define rights.
answer: But do they define justice?

question: Ah. Justice. The banner behind which the English marched as they gobbled up a quarter of the world? Justice, my boy, is only relative to who's in charge.
answer: And how long they stay in charge is only relative to how well they dispense that justice... ... with all due respect.

question: The library, mein leib. I can't figure out if you're brave or foolish.
answer: Why is that, sir?

question: You come here to ask for permission to see my daughter. Correct?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: And knowing who I am, what I stand for, do you think this sort of discussion is going to put that request in a favorable light?
answer: I thought a man of your intellectual reputation wouldn't want his daughter seeing someone who didn't think.

question: Let me give you some advice then. You're right. I admire a keen mind. But intellectual reputation or not, I am first a Marais, a member of the Volk. And if you're trying to impress a member of the Volk with your intellect, don't do it espousing liberal ideas picked up in an English private school.
answer: These ideas I picked up somewhere else.

question: No doubt from an expert on race relations.
answer: Actually, sir, from an expert on cactus.

question: Actually, sir, from an expert on cactus.
answer: Ja. Perfect. You will excuse me, please. This I do not normally without permission do, ja? But to catch the expression. After all, it is the expression that is important. Ja? Without the expression the human being is just a lump of meat. You have some problems, I think. I am Professor Karl von Vollensteen.

question: I'm P.K.
answer: Such a young person with such an

question: That was how I met Doc, as he insisted I call him. A chance meeting between a directionless seven-year-old boy and an old German professor out collecting cacti on the African bush veldt. So began my education. Doc believed the brain had two functions and that the South African public school system unfortunately dealt with only one.
answer: The brain, P.K., has two functions. It is the best reference library ever, which is a good thing to have. Ja? But also from it comes original thought. In school you will get all filled up with the facts. Here your brain will learn where to look, how to look, how to think. And then you will have for yourself all the brains that have ever been.

question: Doc knew everything. He had a love of learning. But his real passion was centered around two things -- music and cacti. CUT TO: Until he was fifty, Doc had a successful career as a concert pianist all over Europe. On his fiftieth birthday he gave it all up and moved to South Africa. From that point on it was all cactus. CUT TO: Every specimen Doc found would be carefully photographed and catalogued.
answer: If God would choose a plant to represent Him, I think He would choose of all plants the cactus. This one plant has all the blessings He tried but failed to give man. It is true. Look. The cactus is humble but not submissive. It grows where no other plant will grow. The sun bakes its back, the wind rips it from cliffs, or drowns it in the dry desert sand. Not a complaint. In good times or bad it will still flower. It protects itself from danger. But it harms no other plant. It

question: Doc was a hard man to disagree with. So when he decided I must spend as much time with him to remedy the flaw in my educational environment I didn't argue. CUT TO: Appealing to my grandfather's stoic belief in the primacy of European culture in all its forms, Doc offered to instruct me in piano in return for my helping him locate and gather his precious cacti. As a student of music I was never more than adequate, something I suspect Doc knew from the start. It is the love of music that is most important, he would tell me, and I would believe him.
answer: Everything fits, P.K. Nothing is unexplained. Nature is one big chain reaction. Everything depends on everything else. From the smallest to the biggest. Always in life an idea starts small like a tree. This tree can grow so high it can touch the face of the sky. But this little vine can choke it and keep it small. Most people are like these vines. Afraid of new ideas. Afraid to let things grow. Always listen to yourself. Follow your own idea. If you are wrong, so what? You learn something. And with learning you grow stronger. And if you are right at the beginning? An even bigger bonus.

question: I roamed the kloofs and ridges, the dry riverbeds and jungle floors with Doc for over a year, learning more than I realize even today. I also played a lot more 'God Save the King' due to my new musical celebrity. Barberton was a very proper English town with a proper square, a wide main street, and the colonials' overblown patriotism for a homeland most people had never seen, hanging in the air like fine dust. Not quite seen, but there nonetheless. CUT TO: The only Afrikaaners to live in Barberton were sent there to work at the government prison, just outside town. Germany had covertly supported the Boers in their two unsuccessful wars against British rule, supplying food and medical supplies as well as ample stocks of ammunition. Germany was an old friend, a trusted friend. And in a country where a handshake is a friendship and a friendship a bond for life, as the war in Europe grew fiercer tensions in Barberton heated up. Suspicion was afoot. Spies were everywhere.
answer: Grammar P.K., if there is one thing I know you to be that is a lot more than just satisfactory. Ja?

question: But I don't want to be known as a brain.

question: Who do you think gets beaten up on all the time in school?
answer: My boy, to be smart is not a sin. But to be smart and not use it, that is sin number one. And as for getting beat up on, use your brain to figure out how not to be. He hands PK the report card, his displeasure obvious. As they crest the hill the cottage comes INTO VIEW along with a parked Army car and two armed soldiers leaning against it. Seeing Doc and PK, the soldiers smarten up, raising their rifles and advancing. Again it begins. The stupidity. Do not be frightened.

answer: No.

question: And the rest we throw away. Geel Piet fidgets. He drops his head, speaking low.

question: I don't understand.
answer: Is like this. You see how hard the life is for the people here in prison. Only little pleasure they take from this hard life maybe sometimes when no one watching late at night -- a little smoke. Now with the big war in Europe tobacco is plenty hard to get outside. Inside it is gone. We are the forgotten in here.

question: We have bunches of leaves at home. I'll bring a whole bucketful tomorrow.

question: I don't understand.

question: In a public match. Not in a gym. Not yet anyway. The Boer is a funny people. Outside the ring the black is not equal. Inside he is. But only in private, not in public. So I keep my mouth shut, the police go a little blind, and that's that. It's a crazy world, huh? Work him on the heavy bag.
answer: Six, seven, eight, nine, ten. That's it. You wanted to see us, Mr. G.?

question: Close the door. Someone I got a lot of respect for asked me to make a request. He wants to put you in a match.

answer: A black fighter! They want him to fight a black fighter?

answer: Out of the question. Not even up for discussion. C'mon, P.K.

answer: I don't know.

answer: There's an African myth about an outsider who comes one day and unites all the tribes into one against their oppressors. They call it the myth of Onoshobishobi Ingelosi -- the tadpole angel. That chanting at the school championships?

question: For you?
answer: I haven't heard it in years.

question: And how did this honor fall on your broad back?
answer: I told you about bringing tobacco to the prisoners at Barberton? Well after that was going for a while I learned that even though they could send and receive letters, they never did. They couldn't read or write.

question: So you did it for them.
answer: Right.

question: And after that?
answer: A clothing program for their families and a food program. One thing sort of led to another.

question: I can see where 'angel' would be an appropriate title. But it was, uh, this Geel Piet who was really behind all of it, wasn't it?
answer: He was very good at pointing things out.

question: Man like that should be running a country, not rotting in prison.
answer: He's not in prison anymore. He's dead.

question: I see you, Nguni.
answer: I see you, P.K. You have heard my request?

question: Yes. Why do you make it?

answer: That the Onoshobishobi Ingelosi who is a chief must fight the one who one day will be a chief.

question: But it's not true that I'm a chief.
answer: Who knows what is true and what is not. The legend of Onoshobishobi Ingelosi is very powerful among the people. They see you box the Boer and always you win. They have heard the stories from Barberton. The people live with little hope. They must see if the spirit of the boy still lives in the man.

question: And if I lose? If the spirit of the Onoshobishobi Ingelosi does not exist in me anymore, then what will they live with?
answer: Less hope. But still they must

answer: I'm scared for you, PK.

answer: I hate it when you tease me.

question: Sorry.
answer: No you're not.

answer: I better go.

answer: Yes, sir.

answer: Lord Byron was a boxer, sir. And I've never heard anyone question his intellectual integrity.

answer: Actually, sir, there are several recorded instances of Lord Byron engaging in matches for quite large sums of money.

question: Let's move along, shall we? As your presentational you've requested to read from a work of your own fiction.
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Well, then, let us hope we'll be treated to the stirrings of another Byron.
answer: The Concerto for the Southland and the Death of Geel Piet. His name was Geel Piet -- yellow Peter. He was a mix of half the blood in Africa -- Dutch, Portuguese, Zulu, Sotha, and who knew what else. His father When I met him he had spent forty of his fifty-five years in one South African prison or another. He was a thief, a con man, a black marketeer. He may even have killed a man or two in his time. But despite all that he was one of the kindest, wisest, most self-effacing persons I ever knew. He was my teacher; he was my friend. FADE TO: Geel Piet bore no animosity, held no hate. Should a guard beat him he regarded it as self-inflicted, You know every time they do that I want to jump up and say I'm just a twelve-year-old. I'm not anything else.

question: He's right. Wunderbar. You are the smartest of us all. Geel Piet smiles as he lifts the watering pot to exit. A truncheon stops him. All turn to Sergeant Bormann.
answer: A kaffir smarter than all of us? You are a strange German, Professor.

question: No, Sergeant. God willing.
answer: And you, too, little Rooinek. But you, kaffir, Hitler comes or goes... You are going to stay with me. And I will find out all your secrets once your friends are gone. One slip... I have you. Get out of here. You see, Professor, they are not like us. A white man would scream bloody murder.

question: I want to address these filthy kaffirs but I don't have a translator.
answer: I'll translate.

question: You can speak Zulu, PK?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: All right. Listen up. Tell them this concert is the gift to them from the professor who, even though he is in prison, is not a dirty criminal like them but a man of culture and learning.
answer: The Kommandant welcomes you and looks forward to the great singing.

question: For such a man I am happy to do this. But one hair of trouble and it's finish.
answer: He hopes each tribe will sing its best and bring honor to its people.

answer: He says tonight let us be one people under the African sky.

question: You did a good job.
answer: Thank you, sir.

question: Professor?
answer: No! Geel Piet died of massive internal hemorrhage, the result of Bormann's ramming a truncheon up into the little man's body until his entrails spilled out. When I reached him he was already dead. I sat there crying, stroking his head and crying with African

question: No! Geel Piet died of massive internal hemorrhage, the result of Bormann's ramming a truncheon up into the little man's body until his entrails spilled out. When I reached him he was already dead. I sat there crying, stroking his head and crying with African
answer: Thank you very much. You will be notified as to the University's decision by mail. Point of curiousity. Your headmaster told me your work is somewhat autobiographical.

question: Yes, sir.
answer: This Bormann, he was real?

answer: Was justice ever served?

question: God, he hits like a truck.
answer: He's going for the quick knockout. He can't keep it up. Soon the truck runs out of gas.

answer: He's had it. He's got no strength in his punch.

question: Could've fooled me.
answer: I'm telling you.

question: Three... four... five... ... seven... eight... nine... How many fingers?
answer: Six.

question: Where are you?
answer: In a fight behind on points.

answer: Maria Marais with a rooinek at the Senior Dance? What will people think?

question: They'll think what they think and I'll think what I think.
answer: And what is that?

answer: I would be honored to be your escort.

question: I didn't doubt it for a minute.
answer: I'll give you a boost. PK stirrups his hands. Maria boosts up to the first branch of the tree. She crests the wall.

question: Please excuse me for coming like a thief by the window.
answer: You speak English? You are a great fighter, Gideon.

question: When you say to me, Onoshobishobi Ingelosi means nothing, you are right. And you are wrong. The legend gives the people hope for a good tomorrow. But hope alone will not make a good tomorrow for the people. You cannot write our letters, get us clothes, food, work. These things we must do ourselves, so we can be part of this country's good tomorrow. If we are not, the hope will disappear. The people will grow tired. The tired will grow angry and there will be no good tomorrow for anybody -- black or white.
answer: What are you asking from me?

answer: We get our knowledge in schools, Gideon. We're not born with it.

answer: You have schools.

question: Second greatest in this room, Gideon.
answer: You are asking me for a lot, young man.

answer: You are asking me to put the reputation of this school in jeopardy.
